Chat Completions.name: Chat Completions
Chat Completions.description: Given a list of messages comprising a conversation, the model will return a response.

request_type.name: messages
request_type.description: A list of messages comprising the conversation so far.

_SystemMessage.name: content
_SystemMessage.description: The contents of the system message.

_SystemMessage.name: role
_SystemMessage.description: The role of the messages author, in this case system.

_SystemMessage.name: name
_SystemMessage.description: An optional name for the participant. Provides the model information to differentiate between participants of the same role.

_UserMessage.name: content
_UserMessage.description: The contents of the user message.

_UserMessage.name: role
_UserMessage.description: The role of the messages author, in this case user.

_UserMessage.name: name
_UserMessage.description: An optional name for the participant. Provides the model information to differentiate between participants of the same role.

_AssistantMessage.name: content
_AssistantMessage.description: The contents of the assistant message. Required unless tool_calls or function_call is specified.

_AssistantMessage.name: refusal
_AssistantMessage.description: The refusal message by the assistant.

_AssistantMessage.name: role
_AssistantMessage.description: The role of the messages author, in this case assistant.

_AssistantMessage.name: name
_AssistantMessage.description: An optional name for the participant. Provides the model information to differentiate between participants of the same role.

_AssistantMessage.name: tool_calls
_AssistantMessage.description: The tool calls generated by the model, such as function calls.

values.name: id
values.description: The ID of the tool call.

values.name: type
values.description: The type of the tool. Currently, only function is supported.

values.name: function
values.description: The function that the model called.

values.name: name
values.description: The name of the function to call.

values.name: arguments
values.description: The arguments to call the function with, as generated by the model in JSON format. Note that the model does not always generate valid JSON, and may hallucinate parameters not defined by your function schema. Validate the arguments in your code before calling your function.

request_type.name: model
request_type.description: ID of the model to use.

request_type.name: frequency_penalty
request_type.description: Number between -2.0 and 2.0. Positive values penalize new tokens based on their existing frequency in the text so far, decreasing the model's likelihood to repeat the same line verbatim.

request_type.name: logit_bias
request_type.description: Modify the likelihood of specified tokens appearing in the completion.\nAccepts a JSON object that maps tokens (specified by their token ID in the tokenizer) to an associated bias value from -100 to 100. Mathematically, the bias is added to the logits generated by the model prior to sampling. The exact effect will vary per model, but values between -1 and 1 should decrease or increase likelihood of selection; values like -100 or 100 should result in a ban or exclusive selection of the relevant token.

request_type.name: logprobs
request_type.description: Whether to return log probabilities of the output tokens or not. If true, returns the log probabilities of each output token returned in the `content` of `message`.

request_type.name: top_logprobs
request_type.description: An integer between 0 and 20 specifying the number of most likely tokens to return at each token position, each with an associated log probability. `logprobs` must be set to `true` if this parameter is used.

request_type.name: max_tokens
request_type.description: The maximum number of (https://platform.openai.com/tokenizer) that can be generated in the chat completion. The total length of input tokens and generated tokens is limited by the model's context length. (https://cookbook.openai.com/examples/how_to_count_tokens_with_tiktoken) for counting tokens.

request_type.name: n
request_type.description: How many chat completion choices to generate for each input message. Note that you will be charged based on the number of generated tokens across all of the choices. Keep `n` as `1` to minimize costs.

request_type.name: presence_penalty
request_type.description: Number between -2.0 and 2.0. Positive values penalize new tokens based on whether they appear in the text so far, increasing the model's likelihood to talk about new topics.

request_type.name: seed
request_type.description: This feature is in Beta. If specified, our system will make a best effort to sample deterministically, such that repeated requests with the same seed and parameters should return the same result. Determinism is not guaranteed, and you should refer to the system_fingerprint response parameter to monitor changes in the backend.

request_type.name: service_tier
request_type.description:
Specifies the latency tier to use for processing the request. This parameter is relevant for customers subscribed to the scale tier service:

- If set to 'auto', the system will utilize scale tier credits until they are exhausted.
- If set to 'default', the request will be processed using the default service tier with a lower uptime SLA and no latency guarentee.
- When not set, the default behavior is 'auto'.
When this parameter is set, the response body will include the service_tier utilized.

request_type.name: stop
request_type.description: Up to 4 sequences where the API will stop generating further tokens.

request_type.name: stream
request_type.description: If set, partial message deltas will be sent, like in ChatGPT. Tokens will be sent as data-only (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Server-sent_events/Using_server-sent_events#Event_stream_format) as they become available, with the stream terminated by a `data: ` message. (https://cookbook.openai.com/examples/how_to_stream_completions).

return_type.name: id
return_type.description: A unique identifier for the chat completion.

return_type.name: choices
return_type.description: A list of chat completion choices. Can be more than one if n is greater than 1.

values.name: finish_reason
values.description: The reason the model stopped generating tokens. This will be `stop` if the model hit a natural stop point or a provided stop sequence, `length` if the maximum number of tokens specified in the request was reached, `content_filter` if content was omitted due to a flag from our content filters, `tool_calls` if the model called a tool, or `function_call` (deprecated) if the model called a function.

values.name: index
values.description: The index of the choice in the list of choices.

values.name: message
values.description: A chat completion message generated by the model.

values.name: content
values.description: The contents of the message.

values.name: role
values.description: The role of the author of this message.

values.name: refusal
values.description: The refusal message generated by the model.

values.name: tool_calls
values.description: The tool calls generated by the model, such as function calls.

values.name: id
values.description: The ID of the tool call.

values.name: type
values.description: The type of the tool. Currently, only function is supported.

values.name: function
values.description: The function that the model called.

values.name: name
values.description: The name of the function to call.

values.name: arguments
values.description: The arguments to call the function with, as generated by the model in JSON format. Note that the model does not always generate valid JSON, and may hallucinate parameters not defined by your function schema. Validate the arguments in your code before calling your function.

values.name: logprobs
values.description: Log probability information for the choice.

return_type.name: created
return_type.description: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) of when the chat completion was created.

return_type.name: model
return_type.description: The model used for the chat completion.

return_type.name: object
return_type.description: The object type, which is always `chat.completion`.

return_type.name: usage
return_type.description: Usage statistics for the completion request.

values.name: completion_tokens
values.description: Number of tokens in the generated completion.

values.name: prompt_tokens
values.description: Number of tokens in the prompt.

values.name: total_tokens
values.description: Total number of tokens used in the request (prompt + completion).

return_type.name: service_tier
return_type.description: The service tier used for processing the request. This field is only included if the service_tier parameter is specified in the request.

return_type.name: system_fingerprint
return_type.description: This fingerprint represents the backend configuration that the model runs with.\n\nCan be used in conjunction with the `seed` request parameter to understand when backend changes have been made that might impact determinism.

Chat.name: Chat
Chat.description: The Chat API is a specialized programming interface designed to allow users to interact with natural language processing models like GPT-3, and GPT-4. These models can be used to generate human-like responses to various inputs and queries.

request_type.name: providers
request_type.description: It can be one (ex: 'amazon' or 'google') or multiple provider(s) (ex: 'amazon,microsoft,google') that the data will be redirected to in order to get the processed results. Providers can also be invoked with specific models (ex: providers: 'amazon/model1, amazon/model2, google/model3')

request_type.name: fallback_providers
request_type.description: Providers in this list will be used as fallback if the call to provider in providers parameter fails. To use this feature, you must input only one provider in the `providers` parameter. but you can put up to 5 fallbacks. They will be tried in the same order they are input, and it will stop to the first provider who doesn't fail. Doesn't work with async subfeatures.

request_type.name: response_as_dict
request_type.description:
Optional : When set to true (default), the response is an object of responses with providers names as keys :

`{"google" : { "status": "success", ... }, }`

When set to false the response structure is a list of response objects :

``.

request_type.name: attributes_as_list
request_type.description:
Optional : When set to false (default) the structure of the extracted items is list of objects having different attributes :

`{'items': }`

When it is set to true, the response contains an object with each attribute as a list :

`{ "attribute_1": , "attribute_2": }`

request_type.name: show_original_response
request_type.description: Optional : Shows the original response of the provider.\n\nWhen set to true, a new attribute original_response will appear in the response object.

request_type.name: text
request_type.description: Start your conversation here...

request_type.name: chatbot_global_action
request_type.description: A system message that helps set the behavior of the assistant. For example, 'You are a helpful assistant'.

request_type.name: previous_history
request_type.description: A list containing all the previous conversations between the user and the chatbot AI. Each item in the list should be a dictionary with two keys: 'role' and 'message'. The 'role' key specifies the role of the speaker and can have the values 'user' or 'assistant'. The 'message' key contains the text of the conversation from the respective role. For example: . This format allows easy identification of the speaker's role and their corresponding message.

values.name: parameters
values.description:
The tool's parameters are specified using a JSON Schema object. Detailed format documentation is available in the JSON Schema reference.

Make sure to well describe each parameter for best results.

Example for a weather tool:

`{"type": "object","properties": {"location": {"type": "string""description": "The geographical location for which weather data is requested."},"unit": {"type": "string", "enum": "description": "The unit of measurement for temperature."}},"required": }`

request_type.name: temperature
request_type.description: Higher values mean the model will take more risks and value 0 (argmax sampling) works better for scenarios with a well-defined answer.

request_type.name: max_tokens
request_type.description: The maximum number of tokens to generate in the completion. The token count of your prompt plus max_tokens cannot exceed the model's context length.

request_type.name: available_tools
request_type.description: A list of tools the model may generate the right arguments for.

values.name: parameters
values.description:
The tool's parameters are specified using a JSON Schema object. Detailed format documentation is available in the JSON Schema reference.

Make sure to well describe each parameter for best results.

Example for a weather tool:

`{"type": "object","properties": {"location": {"type": "string""description": "The geographical location for which weather data is requested."},"unit": {"type": "string", "enum": "description": "The unit of measurement for temperature."}},"required": }`

request_type.name: tool_results
request_type.description: List of results obtained from applying the tool_call arguments to your own tool.

values.name: id
values.description: the id of the tool_call used to generate result

values.name: result
values.description: the result of your function

code.python:
import json
import requests

headers = {"Authorization": "Bearer {{ TOKEN }}"}

url = "https://api.edenai.run/v2/text/chat"
payload = {
    "providers": "openai/gpt-4o",
    "text": "Hello I need your help!",
    "chatbot_global_action": "Act as an assistant",
    "previous_history": [],
    "temperature": 0.0,
    "max_tokens": 150,
}

response = requests.post(url, json=payload, headers=headers)

result = response.json()
print(result['openai/gpt-4o']['generated_text'])

response.content: Example code for making a POST request using cURL.
Example code for making a POST request using cURL.
